steps.title: Bring water to a boil and let it cool to around 175 °F (79 °C).
steps.content: Bring water to a boil and let it cool to around 175 °F (79 °C). Heat water in a stovetop or electric kettle until it begins to boil. Then, turn off the heat and remove the lid so the water cools faster. Let the water cool for about 5 minutes or until it reaches 175 °F (79 °C). [1] X Research source Dina Garcia, RD, LDN, CLT. Nutritionist. [2] X Research source Using boiling hot water can burn the green tea, which will make it taste bitter and unpleasant.

steps.title: Place 1 tea bag in your teacup.
steps.content: Place 1 tea bag in your teacup. It's important that you keep the ratio of 1 tea bag for every 1 cup (240 ml) of water, so if you want to make more than 1 cup of green tea, consider placing 2 or 3 bags in a teapot. This will give you room to add more water. [3] X Research source If you have time, warm the teacup before you make the green tea. Just fill the teacup with hot water and let it sit for about 30 seconds. Then, pour out the water.

steps.title: Pour 1 cup (240 ml) of hot water over the tea bag.
steps.content: Pour 1 cup (240 ml) of hot water over the tea bag. Carefully pour the 175 °F (79 °C) degree water into the teacup. [4] X Research source Dina Garcia, RD, LDN, CLT. Nutritionist. If you have a saucer or small plate, place this on top of the teacup to prevent the steam from escaping and cooling the tea. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Steep the tea for 2 to 3 minutes.
steps.content: Steep the tea for 2 to 3 minutes. If you prefer a light, delicate flavor, leave the tea to brew for only 2 minutes. For a slightly stronger, earthy flavor, brew it for a total of 3 minutes. [6] X Research source Don't brew the green tea for more than 3-4 minutes or the flavor will become bitter. [7] X Research source Dina Garcia, RD, LDN, CLT. Nutritionist.

steps.title: Remove the tea bag and sip the green tea.
steps.content: Remove the tea bag and sip the green tea. Lift the tea bag out of the teacup and let the excess drip into the cup. Set the tea bag aside to use again or discard it. Now you can drink your hot green tea or flavor it with a little honey or lemon. [8] X Research source Avoid squeezing the tea bag because this will release bitter components into the tea.

steps.title: Heat water between 170 and 176 °F (77 and 80 °C).
steps.content: Heat water between 170 and 176 °F (77 and 80 °C). If you're using a stovetop or electric water kettle, bring the water to a boil and then turn off the heat. Let the water cool for about 5 minutes so the temperature is between 170 and 176 °F (77 and 80 °C). [9] X Research source Always start with water that you haven't boiled before. This will help the leaves open as the tea steeps.

steps.title: Place 1 teaspoon (2 g) of loose-leaf green tea into a small teapot.
steps.content: Place 1 teaspoon (2 g) of loose-leaf green tea into a small teapot. You can use a small measuring spoon or a digital scale to measure the loose leaves for your tea. Put the leaves directly into the teapot or into the infuser basket if your teapot has one. [10] X Research source If you have time, you can pour hot water into the teapot to warm it up. Then, pour out the water and place the tea leaves in the bottom.

steps.title: Pour 3⁄4 cup (180 ml) of the hot water over the leaves.
steps.content: Pour 3 ⁄ 4 cup (180 ml) of the hot water over the leaves. You should see the leaves begin to unfurl as the heat from the water causes them to open. If your teapot has a lid, place it on top of the pot to trap the steam. [11] X Research source You could also place a small saucer over the top of the teapot to prevent the steam from escaping.

steps.title: Steep the green tea for 1 to 2 minutes.
steps.content: Steep the green tea for 1 to 2 minutes. Set a timer for 1 minute and then use a spoon to taste the tea. If you like the flavor, you can stop the infusion or continue to steep the tea until it's strong enough for your taste. [12] X Research source If you're using 1 tablespoon (5 g) of tea leaves, steep the tea for a much shorter time. Try tasting it in 10-second increments until it's as flavorful as you like.

steps.title: Strain the leaves or remove the infuser basket and drink the tea.
steps.content: Strain the leaves or remove the infuser basket and drink the tea. You can lift the basket out of the tea so the excess drips into the pot. If your teapot doesn't have an infuser basket, set a tea strainer over a small teacup and slowly pour the green tea into your cup. Sip the tea while it's hot. [13] X Research source Squeeze a little lemon or stir some honey into the tea if you'd like to add a bright flavor. You can save the tea leaves and brew 1 to 2 more pots of tea with them. Keep in mind that each additional brew will need less steeping time since the leaves are already opened.

steps.title: Place a fine mesh strainer over a matcha tea bowl.
steps.content: Place a fine mesh strainer over a matcha tea bowl. If you don't have a small matcha tea bowl (also called a matcha-chawan), you can use a teacup or a small kitchen prep bowl. Ensure that the bowl is heat proof. [14] X Research source If you like, you can warm the tea bowl so it doesn't cool down your hot matcha tea. To warm the tea bowl, fill it with boiling hot water and leave it for 30 seconds before carefully dumping out the water.

steps.title: Sift 1 1/2 teaspoons (2 g) of matcha powder into the tea bowl.
steps.content: Sift 1 1/2 teaspoons (2 g) of matcha powder into the tea bowl. Measure the matcha powder into the fine mesh strainer. Then, use the back of a spoon to gently push the powder through the strainer so it falls into the tea bowl. [15] X Research source The sifted matcha should look like bright green dust in the tea bowl.

steps.title: Bring water to a boil and let it cool to between 180 and 190 °F (82 and 88 °C).
steps.content: Bring water to a boil and let it cool to between 180 and 190 °F (82 and 88 °C). Since matcha green tea doesn't use a lot of water, you can bring about 1 cup (240 ml) to a boil using a stovetop or electric kettle. Once the water boils, remove it from the heat and let it cool about 1 minute so the temperature drops. [16] X Research source Start with clean, fresh water that hasn't been boiled before in order to get the best tasting matcha green tea.

steps.title: Pour 1⁄4 cup (59 ml) of the hot water into the tea bowl.
steps.content: Pour 1 ⁄ 4 cup (59 ml) of the hot water into the tea bowl. Slowly pour the 180 and 190 °F (82 and 88 °C) degree water into the matcha powder that's in your tea bowl. [17] X Research source The powder should begin to dissolve as soon as the hot water hits it. More of a matcha latte person? Learn how users make matcha lattes on wikiHow's "How do you guys make matcha lattes at home?" forum page .

steps.title: Whisk the mixture for 20 to 60 seconds to make matcha green tea.
steps.content: Whisk the mixture for 20 to 60 seconds to make matcha green tea. Use a bamboo whisk (also called a chasen) to combine the tea powder with the water. Try to keep your wrist loose and whisk in a circle if you'd like thin tea. If you want thicker, foamy tea, whisk quickly in a back and forth motion. [18] X Research source To create the thin, smooth tea, whisk for closer to 20 seconds. You'll need to whisk for around 1 minute if you want foam on the top of your tea.

steps.title: Sip the matcha green tea while it's hot.
steps.content: Sip the matcha green tea while it's hot. You can drink the tea directly out of the tea bowl that you just made it in. Try to enjoy the tea as soon as you've finished whisking it because the powder will settle if the tea sits for long. [19] X Research source In order to fully enjoy the experience of drinking matcha green tea, cup the tea bowl with both hands and bring it to your face. Breathe in the smell of the tea and relax before you begin drinking.
